data.title: The Ring of Fire/ "1632" series by pub date, with notes on following threads - Chicago Public Library
data.meta_description:
The Ring of Fire/ "1632" series by pub date, with notes on following threads by AnneTG - a community-created list : Listing all novels/anthologies in the series (as of May 2018) in order of the pub date, not their chronological place within the series.
Anthologies and "merged novels" mixed in with straight novels, followed by "Grantville Gazette " issues, and finally with the related "Assiti Shard" novels listed last.

One of the benefits of this series is that the setting is so rich that multiple story-lines exist, but sometimes books overlap and might contain spoilers for other books with a subsequent publication date. I've tried to indicate such overlap where it might make sense to read the books out of order, or where it might be possible to skip some books in order to follow regional threads without exposure to spoilers. (And I have a VERY broad definition of what constitutes a spoiler.)
data.text:
02 - published August 2002. _____ Necessary prequel: "1632" 02 - published August 2002. _____ Necessary prequel: "1632" Show less

03 - anthology - published January 2004. _____ Necessary prequels: "1632" and "1633". Some of the characters (most notably, the Stone ...Show more 03 - anthology - published January 2004. _____ Necessary prequels: "1632" and "1633". Some of the characters (most notably, the Stone family) in subsequent books are either introduced or expanded beyond mere mentions, but the subsequent books adequately bring the reader up to speed. The only story that might be considered fully "necessary" might be the final novela, "The Wallenstein Gambit", because it sets up and explains an important political situation that did NOT happen in the real world. Show less

All copies in use Availability details

05 - "melded novel" (multiple linked short stories) - published May 2006. Despite the credit in the catalog, Eric Flint acts more like an editor than sole author (and he makes this clear in the author's note). 05 - "melded novel" (multiple linked short stories) - published May 2006. Despite the credit in the catalog, Eric Flint acts more like an editor than sole author (and he makes this clear in the author's note). Show less

All copies in use Availability details

06 - published October 2006 Direct sequel to "The Galileo Affair". Some overlap with "1633" and "1634 The Baltic War", but does not have any real spoilers for those books. 06 - published October 2006 Direct sequel to "The Galileo Affair". Some overlap with "1633" and "1634 The Baltic War", but does not have any real spoilers for those books. Show less

07 - published May 2007 _____ Direct sequel to "1633" - follows so closely that it's more like Volume 2 of the same novel. May have allusions to...Show more 07 - published May 2007 _____ Direct sequel to "1633" - follows so closely that it's more like Volume 2 of the same novel. May have allusions to events in the book "The Galileo Affair" and the novela "The Wallenstein Gambit" from the anthology "Ring of Fire", but none too spoilerish. Show less

08 - published October 2007 _____ Expands the scope of the novels to include Austria and Bavaria, with significant development in the Low Countries. 08 - published October 2007 _____ Expands the scope of the novels to include Austria and Bavaria, with significant development in the Low Countries. Show less

09 - anthology - published January 2008 _____ Several stories constitute preludes to full novels, those novels adequately cover the same information. A p...Show more 09 - anthology - published January 2008 _____ Several stories constitute preludes to full novels, those novels adequately cover the same information. A possible exception is the novela ""The Austro-Hungarian Connection" by Eric Flint, which establishes characters and events that are continued in both "The Saxon Uprising" and "The Vienna Waltz." Also contains the story "A Trip to Amsterdam" which gives the reader an interesting introduction to the international economic charges that this series is developing, previously seen mostly via side characters in the "Grantville Gazette". Show less

All copies in use Availability details

10 - published December 2008 _____ Resumes the stories of characters mostly appearing in short stories and "The Ram Rebellion". Concentrates on ...Show more 10 - published December 2008 _____ Resumes the stories of characters mostly appearing in short stories and "The Ram Rebellion". Concentrates on interpersonal relationships within the town of Grantville, but includes an incident at the end which affects political events in the series generally. Show less

11 - published December 2009 _____ An anthology combining four short stories (2 previously published in "The Grantville Gazettes"). As of Octobe...Show more 11 - published December 2009 _____ An anthology combining four short stories (2 previously published in "The Grantville Gazettes"). As of October 2021 this book is not available at the Chicago Public Library, but it does not establish any major characters or plot points that cannot be understood from context in subsequent novels. Show less

12 - published October 2010 _____ Follows the events of the novel "1634: The Baltic War", which is essential for full appreciation of this book...Show more 12 - published October 2010 _____ Follows the events of the novel "1634: The Baltic War", which is essential for full appreciation of this book. Probably also necessary to read "1634: The Bavarian Crisis". However, other than those two books, sufficient context for other works set in 1634 is provided for readers who have skipped those other books. Show less

15 - published June 2012 _____ Well-integrated novelization of the "Butterflies in the Kremlin" stories, originally published in The Grantville...Show more 15 - published June 2012 _____ Well-integrated novelization of the "Butterflies in the Kremlin" stories, originally published in The Grantville Gazettes. Contains minimal references to events in previously published novels - it's recommended that this novel be preceded by a reading of "1632" and "1633", but otherwise a reader probably does not need knowledge of the other stories or novels. Show less

16 - published October 2012 _____ Direct sequel to "The Cannon Law". Very few allusions to events outside of southern Europe, but it does contai...Show more 16 - published October 2012 _____ Direct sequel to "The Cannon Law". Very few allusions to events outside of southern Europe, but it does contain a tangential spoiler to "1634: The Baltic War" in that characters who were endangered in that 2007 book reappear (or their activities are referred to) in this one. Show less

18 - published October 2013 ______ Contains significant spoilers for "1635: The Eastern Front" and MASSIVE spoilers for "1636: The Saxon ...Show more 18 - published October 2013 ______ Contains significant spoilers for "1635: The Eastern Front" and MASSIVE spoilers for "1636: The Saxon Uprising". (The plot for "The Devil's Opera" runs concurrently with the events described in "The Saxon Uprising" and makes frequent references to that prior novel.) __________ Features characters who appeared in previously published short stories by David Carrico, but this novel is excellent in re-introducing those characters to readers who may not have access to those prior works. (A full list of prior stories featuring these characters is found at https://ericflint.fandom.com/wiki/David_Carrico ) Show less

19 - published January 2014 - A 2-part "melded novel" (2 series of multiple linked short stories). The first half features references to the s...Show more 19 - published January 2014 - A 2-part "melded novel" (2 series of multiple linked short stories). The first half features references to the significant events in the Low Countries that occur in the novel "1633" and "1634: The Baltic War" (primarily the former). Show less

20 - published June 2014 __________ Requires understanding of the events following the outcome of "1634: The Baltic War". Also helpful (but not...Show more 20 - published June 2014 __________ Requires understanding of the events following the outcome of "1634: The Baltic War". Also helpful (but not essential) to have read "1634: The Bavarian Crisis" to understand the political status of Irish mercenaries in the Low Countries. Contains a few allusions (but no real spoilers) to the actions of a side character in the anthology "1636: Seas of Fortune". Show less

22 - published November 2014 _________ Full novel centered on characters previously found in a well-developed series of short stories in "The Grantvi...Show more 22 - published November 2014 _________ Full novel centered on characters previously found in a well-developed series of short stories in "The Grantville Gazette". While various volumes of the Gazette are available, the volume that collected those stories ("The Barbie Consortium") is not available at the Chicago Public Library. However, the novel "The Viennese Waltz" provides an excellent re-introduction of those characters to readers who may be meeting them for the first time. Show less

23 - published July 2015 Takes place almost entirely within France, but contains SIGNIFICANT spoilers for the outcome of the "1635 The Eastern Front...Show more 23 - published July 2015 Takes place almost entirely within France, but contains SIGNIFICANT spoilers for the outcome of the "1635 The Eastern Front"/"1636: The Saxon Uprising" duology. Sufficient context given for those unfamiliar with the series, but it's strongly recommended that readers read the thread of novels leading up to "1636: The Saxon Uprising" first. Also contains a side spoiler for "1635: The Papal Stakes" in that it features the continuing story of a character who faced mortal danger in that prior novel. Show less

24 - published January 2016 _____ Spoilers for "1634: The Baltic War" - features the continuing story of several characters who last appeared in...Show more 24 - published January 2016 _____ Spoilers for "1634: The Baltic War" - features the continuing story of several characters who last appeared in that novel. Also features a character who originated in the South Europe thread who moved to northern Europe, but the fact of his continuing activities represents only a minor spoiler, and sufficient context is given to readers previously unfamiliar with him. Show less
